user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 21.14 is: The Standard Library function memcmp shall not be used to compare null terminated strings.

</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of UtList_DeleteNode:
```c
void UtList_DeleteNode(UtListNode_t *DeleteNode)
{
    UtList_Extract(DeleteNode);

    /* non-data/header nodes shouldn't be free()'ed */
    if (DeleteNode->Data != NULL)
    {
        free(DeleteNode);
    }
}
```
</target_code>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are related to the target function UtList_DeleteNode:
void UtList_Extract(UtListNode_t *ExistingNode)
{
    ExistingNode->Next->Prev = ExistingNode->Prev;
    ExistingNode->Prev->Next = ExistingNode->Next;
    ExistingNode->Next       = ExistingNode;
    ExistingNode->Prev       = ExistingNode;
}
...
typedef struct UtListNodeTag
{
    struct UtListNodeTag *Next;
    struct UtListNodeTag *Prev;
    void *                Data;
    uint32                DataSize;
    uint32                Tag;
} UtListNode_t
...
void UtList_Reset(UtListNode_t *TagHead)
{
    while (!UtList_IsEmpty(TagHead))
    {
        UtList_DeleteNode(TagHead->Next);
    }
}
...
void UtList_Destroy(UtListHead_t *ListHead)
{
    uint32 i;

    for (i = 0; i < ListHead->NumberOfTags; ++i)
    {
        UtList_Reset(&ListHead->Tags[i]);
    }
    free(ListHead);
}
</additional code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation:
I scanned the provided target and related code fragments for any use of the standard library function memcmp or any string comparison of null-terminated strings. None of the fragments contain memcmp calls or string comparison logic. Specific notes:

- UtList_DeleteNode: performs pointer manipulation, a NULL check on DeleteNode->Data and calls free(). No string operations or memcmp usage.
- UtList_Extract: updates Next/Prev pointers and reinitializes the node’s links. No library calls or string comparisons.
- UtListNode_t typedef: defines pointers, void* Data and integer fields. No string data or memcmp usage.
- UtList_Reset: iterates over list nodes and calls UtList_DeleteNode. No memcmp or string comparisons.
- UtList_Destroy: iterates over tags, calls UtList_Reset and free(ListHead). No memcmp or string comparisons.

Therefore there are no code fragments in the provided code that match or potentially violate MISRA C 2023 Rule 21.14 (use of memcmp to compare null-terminated strings). If additional source files exist, they should be checked for any memcmp usage, but within the supplied codebase no suspicious fragments were found.
